Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge erred in applying the physical presence test instead of the qualitative test for residency
Application_Facts: Applicant was absent for 876 days, failing the 1,095-day physical presence requirement in the four years preceding the application
Remedy_Requested: Overturning of the Citizenship Judge's decision
Court_Ruling: Citizenship Judge correctly applied the physical presence test
Defendant_Behavior: Extended absences from Canada during the required period
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged error in legal test application (physical vs. qualitative)
Assessment_Factor: Number of days physically present in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Appeal based on the record before the Citizenship Judge
Review_Standard: Statutory interpretation and correctness of legal test applied
Evidence_Used: Record of applicant's absences and presence in Canada
Application_Basis: Failure to meet statutory physical presence requirement
Evidence_Assessed: Duration and pattern of applicant's absences from Canada
Relief_Sought: Grant of citizenship or remittal for reconsideration
Governing_Rule: Applicants must be physically present in Canada for 1,095 days in the four years before application
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of compliance with physical presence requirement
Outcome: Appeal dismissed; original decision upholding denial of citizenship upheld
Cause_Description: Applicant failed to meet the 1,095-day physical presence requirement due to extensive absences
Evidence_Handling: Reliance on documented travel and residency records
Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant â€“ 876 days absent, only 919 days present
Evidence_Assessment: Absences clearly documented and exceeded allowable limit
Decision_Rationale: No obligation to apply qualitative test; physical presence is a strict statutory requirement
Decision_Making_Body: Citizenship Judge, reviewed by Federal Court
Legal_Standard_Applied: Physical presence test as per statutory requirement
